review_title: Good place to make a living, simple things could make it way better
pros:
- Management seems super lax about flexing work days and taking time off.
- If you're lucky, there are opportunities to travel to some wild places across the world to launch rockets. Launch campaigns are what engineers dream of in college: hands on building stuff, high pressure, on the fly problem solving, and really working as a team.
- Can't imagine not having a 9/80 schedule and if you're somewhat competent you literally never need to work more than 80 hours
- Mobility around the company seems pretty easy if you want to give another discipline or role a shot.
- There's almost nowhere you could reasonably decide to live in the valley where the commute time to work will be bad.
cons:
- High wall cubes really isolate people and its hit or miss whether you end up on a team or wing of the building that's young and lively or completely dead and soul sucking.
- More managers than actual people doing useful work.
- Its defense, so besides the young folk, its generally pretty conservative.

review_title: One year after job offer and no start date
pros: Interviews with other engineers at employer site was a pleasant experience. They seemed very knowledgeable in their field.
cons:
I feel I need to share my experience with NG for anyone who is considering employment with them especially graduating engineering students. I was offered a job as an engineer just before graduation in 2020 which was dependent upon my completion of background checks and clearances. This process took around 5 - 6 months which was communicated and I considered and accepted the lengthy process. After the finalization of these matters I was told that other engineers within the company was to be placed in new positions before I could be given a start date. After another period of time the company stated that they were trying to find work for me. What happened to the original position that I was offered? Currently, I am a year out of school with no work experience and an obvious gap between graduation and now which is unappealing to employers. 

When I accept a position at a company and the preliminaries are finalized I expect the company to follow through with their original offer.

Hopefully, a graduating engineering student or any prospective employee of NG will find this review helpful before committing to NG and find themselves in the same precarious position as I.

pros:
In the Melbourne area, most of the buildings are relatively new and lack the moldy smell common in most defense companies.

The security guards are friendly

Some of the labs are nice and modern
cons:
During my time at Northrop Grumman, none of the new hires were allowed to work from home even when the work was completely on non-classified computers. They were also not allowed to work a flexible schedule. There were 5-10 covid cases per week, most of them in the building I worked in. About every 2 weeks, my lead would hold crowded in person meetings for all the new hires, which lasted about an hour, not give a skype option, and told us to not report how many people were in the room. 

Whenever I gave any notice to my manager about an appointment that would cause me to be late to work, he would say that it's fine in an email, then afterwards, schedule an in person meeting with me and tell me verbally to never get to work past 8am. He would then pry into the details of my appointments and say he was not able to tell anyone because he is bound by HIPAA. He would frequently call me on my off days. Not to talk about work, but to pry into my personal life. I eventually went to ethics regarding all of these issues concerning both my lead and manager. I was fired 4 weeks later. 

We would get monthly emails from the CEO, telling us how much she cares for our safety. However, several members of leadership had proved otherwise.

Compared to other defense companies, Northrop Grumman is lacking in benefits. There are no yearly bonuses and health insurance is more expensive. They also don't give very much paid time off.

job_title: Senior Principal Systems Engineer in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Flexible work arrangements, 9/80 schedule, decent benefits
cons:
If you have a PhD and want to do challenging/interesting work, go somewhere else. I've been trying for nearly two years to get assigned to something like this with no success. I've tried moving to the basic research division, but there is a chronic funding shortage there and so it's nearly impossible to get a full time assignment there. So I keep getting systems engineering roles like risk management, writing requirements verification text, schedule/budget, MBSE, etc. None of this requires a PhD. And for the record, my PhD is in electrical engineering with a focus on IR sensors/lasers from UCLA. This is absolutely a field of work done at Northrup Grumman. Why won't they assign me to a role in this area? Beats me.

Compensation is ok, but nothing close to what you'll make in Bay Area tech.

pros: Work is very stable here even during the COVID-19 pandemic. The name recognition of the company carries good weight.
cons:
-Absolute neglect of proper health and safety conditions at the facility in Sunnyvale. Employees who can do their work in a sufficient manner working remotely were required to come into work 5 days a week on my direct team. Most of our work is done using computers sitting in cubicles, yet there was zero flexibility despite senior leadership saying so. If remote-capable workers are required to come in 5 days a week during the worst part of the pandemic (3% ICU Capacity), why is it that management seems to be absent from the campus? 

-The Sunnyvale campus promised to have a running dashboard of people in isolation and positive cases but no sign of updates after the initial powerpoint 2 months prior.
 
-Management is severely out of touch with the actual employees doing the work. Excessive back-and-forth just to relay the status of work or to confirm a problem. The actual people with technical knowledge are treated extremely poorly. Management hires based on nepotism and do not have a good technical breadth of the work they are conducting. 

-Pay is 10-15% below average for competitive roles in the Bay Area

pros:
Honestly, one of the best jobs I have ever had, the company has tons of additional benefits and hidden gems in there main page internally that can really help with education, personal life, and even professional development.
The people are truly amazing, everyone takes their work seriously and does exactly what they say they are going to as close to the targeted goal as possible which breeds a culture of understanding when things go awry. Everyone is friendly, the people care about each other, has a large veteran community and actually shows their appreciation for the vets in many small ways. Finally, the company truly recognizes when people go above and beyond, giving extra pay for particular accomplishments and rewards and acknowledgement of activities that are otherwise outside of one's scope. With that they also utilize their Continuous Process Improvement more than any company I have ever been with before and use it as a competition between sections to see who has the best ideas and the best implementation of those!
cons: At time the work can dwindle and cause lulls in work availability, leaving floor staff to hunt for work, sometimes resorting to just doing online training for entire days at the worst of times (however, this is not a total negative). Also, interpersonal conflicts do spark up from time to time, even the greatest work places can't escape the rumor mill unfortunately which can stress employees when timelines are short.

review_title: Used to be better. Some good sectors, some not
pros: Some sectors appear to be good, solid places to work. There's interesting, challenging work available if you can find it. If you have a security clearance, there's more interesting work available.
cons:
Avoid the Mission Systems sector. This sector:
1. lost most of the leadership that made it a good sector to work in
2. created a huge matrix based management bureaucracy that consumes any profit from the actual engineers and doesn't do what it was created for
3. uses stack ranking for performance reviews (a quick search will reveal articles on how bad this is for high performing engineers)
4. Lost most of its training budget due to the cost of the matrix. People who want a company that will pay for their continued education should look carefully at what the company offers.

As many others have mention if you care about company culture at all this is not the place for you. It kind of makes you sick to see how your tax dollars are being spent inside of the a government contractor. job_title: Mechanical Engineer II in Washington, DC
pros: Steady employer. Lots of future growth projected throughout space systems sector over next few years, presenting new hiring and promotion opportunities to those seeking it. Appears to have competitive pay in the 0-3 years experience range. Good about accommodating work-from-home arrangements, which accelerated under COVID-19. Good healthcare benefits relative to what we usually get in the US. Fairly good work-life balance depending on job title.
cons: Company could have provided bonus/hazard pay for critical employees who cannot work from home during COVID-19 (national security, manufacturing, etc), which make up a large percentage of the company. Some groups of employees are very understaffed, while other groups are very overstaffed - organization as a whole has difficulty balancing hiring to scale up with their projects, which leads to poor load balancing across the staff (unfortunately common at very large companies.) Suffers from much of the same diversity issues that plague the rest of the engineering community (few women, few black and brown employees, etc.)

job_title: Strategic Planner in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- Work life balance (9/80 schedule, with every other Friday off)
- Pay (above average / on par with industry)
- Customers -- works makes a difference in support of the military
- Products -- cool platforms, products, and systems... great for engineers or other STEM... if you're not an engineer, I'd look elsewhere.
cons:
- Work life balance -- lots of time spent spinning wheels due to little direction and politics = no one wants to make a decision, even simple ones... so you may end up occasionally working that 9/80 Friday they give you (maybe one every 3-4), and you may work some long hours during the week... definitely set boundaries with "leaders"
- Toxic culture, especially at the top (director and VP level). Littler diversity and an "old boys club". They resist change and are rarely opened to new ideas. Consistently take credit for your work and don't let you shine. Will often add two cents just for the sake of it to be heard.
- Fake empathy -- claim to care about attracting young talent, yet keep trying to do things the same tired ways.

review_title: Good, but not great. Decent to good benefits.
pros:
-Welcoming/personable people and culture
-Time off is seldom if ever questioned; quite good flexibility with inevitable appointments life brings
-Culture where work-life balance is encouraged
-9/80 work schedule means every other Friday off
-Typically a low-stress environment
-Design work and team is great and a lot of fun
-Electrical engineering managers are great; typically looking to ensure you like what you are doing and help you grow your skills. Very personable and understanding.
-A collection of very capable engineers, most of which are willing to share their knowledge
-Movement to other areas in company supported and encouraged
cons:
-Pay is now lagging way behind increased cost of living in the Phoenix area
-Loads upon loads of tribal knowledge, red tape, and extremely dense and specific protocols. Pace can be quite slow and tedious as a result.
-Easy to get pigeon-holed into a rather narrow area of expertise where skills growth becomes minimal.
-Dedication to heritage parts and systems can make ingenuity far too difficult
-There is a general paid time off time pool. This means sick time comes from same pool as vacation time. If you are ill, your vacation time takes a hit
-Facilities for hardware development for new designs are quite poor, cramped, and equipment is outdated. Very disappointing. Massively slows down the process.
-Red tape and dense procedural requirements mean that too often it is way too difficult to get simple work done
-Work supporting product production is less than desirable. Too many project and production middle managers with conflicting interests. Work can be slow until suddenly one has to "put out fires" when suddenly everything needs to happen now, now, now. This fluctuation in pace is routine. Unsurprisingly, there is massive employee turnover in this role. Skills used in this role aren't transferable outside company and it gets boring fast.
-Procedural change comes extremely slowly if ever, leading to outdated work modes and tools (example: poorly documented FORTRAN-esque proprietary scripting language that can't do a FOR loop used for product testing).
-Good ol' boy culture with some senior engineers who aren't required to follow same rules and protocols as everybody else. "Busy work" they don't feel like doing but could easily do in hours gets assigned to lower-level engineers for whom it takes days/weeks due to their unfamiliarity with the project. Very inefficient.
-Defense contractor, so employees are held to outdated Department of Defense standards of conduct
-All hours logged based on project you work on. Very tedious.
